channel.title: +MT on Vishvas's notes
channel.description: Recent content in +MT on Vishvas's notes

item.title: Evolution
item.description:
Source: TW

In the closing stages of the age of the dinosaurs, there appeared a small arboreal animal, perhaps just 50 g in weight. With the great extinction decimating the non-avian dinosaurs in the trees, they underwent an ecological release and radiated into the forms like those shown below. They were the plesiadapiforms – the group within which primates – thus our ancestors from the opening of the Cenozoic. Little would have one expected that a descendant of theirs would spread all over the world like a weed by the billions.

item.title: Tool-use
item.description:
50k year old pre-Clovis stone tools from Pedra Furada, north-eastern Brazil, were likely made by capuchin monkeys.

Stone tool use is definitely there other than in Sapajus, Cebus (both platyrrhines or New world Monkeys), Macaca, probably Pongo, Pan & Homo ( Catarrhines (apes&monkeys proper). Are we missing its wider use across simiiform primates? Also has it convergently evolved many times?
